results.content:
Excellent topic coverage. 
It seemed like the intro modules were a little long - showing the 'bad old ways' - but seeing how much slimmer the code for Reactive pattern is, is pretty impressive.
Samples have all worked to this point. Only saw one example where the <h2> text had changed with no mention of it but it was non-consequential.
Clear explanation of the concepts and why they're important.
Also has some mention of NG-4 changes that make this pattern even better.

results.content:
I am a very experienced developer.  I already know why it's a great idea to develop applications in a reactive fashion.  That's why I bought this course.  BUT, the truly important information I need about HOW to actually IMPLEMENT Observables is nested so deeply in this instructor's "ideas about architecture", that's it is very boring and therefore difficult to follow.

I've been trying to get through this for few weeks.  I haven't left a rating until now because I recognize that my own frame of mind can make a big difference.  In order to be fair, I've tried to work through this more than a few times.  

Each time I've tried to get into this important set of tools, the instructors wandering and meandering style either puts me to sleep or makes me angry that I've wasted time and money on this course. 

I'd strongly suggest that the instructor take the time identify the essential mechanisms.  

Describe in a step by step fashion. how to use those - instead of spending countless words and minutes on why to use them.

And make that essential core of material available without all the wandering and meandering.

This wouldn't prevent him from leaving the existing material available to those who need or want it.

response.content: Hello Joe, sorry to hear that. This course is an introduction to reactive programming in the context of Angular. I think it's the case of an advanced developer purchasing a course that is not designed for experts.

There was a higher focus on state than I expected, but that is not to say the knowledge wasn't useful. What I learned was above excellent, my expectations were just different. I will be using RxJS 6 in practice to learn more intricacies of things like operators, which I thought was included here.
In the start of the course it was mentioned that every time an operator would be introduced, there would be breakdown and focus on it. I did not feel that was the case, and I would suggest a quick reference to the marble diagrams in the RxJS documentation would be helpful.

results.content:
The course is good, learnt a lot of different approaches to angular app design and implementations. I have now converted big parts of my current app using these reactive design principals. I finally understand Subjects/Observers and rxjs much better. Thanks.

Bad things are: Using RXJS v 5 operators, very little discussion about operators and how they work, and often felt rushed. The Git repo is also a mess and difficult to navigate - the branch names make no sense and no easy way to get to end of section area.

results.content: Great course. Advanced. Great to take after Max S's Angular course. Covers advanced patterns.  Was a bit hesitant at the start, since he wasn't using services, and didnt mention services in any course roadmap, but he was building up to that.  A bit unclear on when to use Observables in comparison with EventEmitters.  Otherwise very great course, very thought provoking.  You have to start at the beginning and work your way through, as the sections build on each other.  Chances are that you can watch the first section on double speed though, since it's just setup and getting started.  Would be interested in checking out a sequential course from the same creators.

results.content:
Despite of this course is a good start with RxJS, it won't prepare you for hard production.
Pros:
- you have written application, you have to rewrite it with RxJS, so only nutshell. Amazing.
- good and short explanation
Cons:
- using bad practices without even noticing it
- knowledge about RxJS is not enough for production-ready
- testing is not covered at all

I have an experience with RxJs and rolled in to this course to hone this technology and apply it in my production project. Unfortunately, there is absolutely nothing new for me.

results.content:
This is a great course, and covers more advanced subjects and techniques that other regular Angular courses ignore. Even after using Angular now for nearly 3 years I learned a LOT of new things to add to my toolbox.

Many concepts are difficult to understand (IMO) but Vasco does a great job explaining what the section is about, the problem with the 'normal' way of doing it, and explains the benefits of the pure Reactive RxJs way of doing it. Often he will show in code the traditional (pre-Reactive) version, and then convert it over to Reactive RxJs. Everything is explained fully, and I even appreciate how he starts each video with a summary of where he left off from the previous video, and what needs to be done next. Then at the end of each video often will summarize what was done in the video to help solidify the concepts.

He is also careful to have the proper zoom level so you can see all the relevant code in one screen (if possible).

Vasco also will answer any question in the comments within a couple days, which is much appreciated.

My only complaint (and this goes for all his courses) is the "look/feel" of his IDE. Everyone else has switched to a dark editor "theme". Vasco on the other hand insists on the old-school white screen IDE. Oh well... this is just a small complaint compared to the excellent content of the course.

I have hated this course. Honestly I've been finish it because I couldn't get my money back. The subject itself is really interesting, but the instructor made it boring.

My points for what the course is so bad:

1. The instructor never or rarelly answer our questions;
2. There are a lot of classes where the code doesn't compile. You can see in the Q&A;
3. There are a lot of moments where we can see that video were edited. For example: in some moment a method appears or dissapears with no explanation from Instructor;
4. The "app" used as example is completelly useless.
5. The code is note progressive. There are a lot of branches. The result is a lot of CTRLC CTRLV...
6. At some points I notice the this course have another courses of Angular University as requirement.

Anyway, I didn't like it.

results.content:
The instructor knows his stuff but really needs to improve his presentation style because this course is really heavy-going and I know several colleagues who just gave up. The instructor over-labours the Observable Pattern to the point at which the endless repetition made me nearly give up. Almost half the course is obsessed with trying to justify the pattern instead of getting on with the real subject matter, and it's tedious and endlessly repetitive. I really feel the instructor could learn a lot from the best instructors like John Papa and Deborah Kurata - ie.

- a picture can paint a thousand words (or many lessons) Sitting in an iDE and flipping fast around a LOT of code for the whole course is dull and doesn't help "train" people where a single simple diagram would have made everything much clearer.

- Please turn on line numbering in your editor. For those screen capturing code snippets as they follow along this makes a HUGE difference to understanding the code.

- The Structure is all over the place and needs improving. Just one example: Why have a "Smart and Presentational Components Part 1" when there is no other part listed? It turns out a bit is tacked on in the middle of a completely different lesson.  Too often the instructor spends a lot of time explaining what will be covered "In the next lesson" but then the next lesson turns out to be something completely different and what he should have said is "in six lessons time".

- Make it clear the course is NOT about learning RxJS operators. The summary actually claims this was done, but it wasn't. We got a very quick example of less than  a handful of the operators. Those taking the course hoping to penetrate the hundreds of seemingly unfathomable RxJS operators are going to be severely disappointed. Even an important operator like FlatMap isn't used or mentioned.

- The heavy accent and repetitive use of English makes this course harder than most to follow. There is no need to keep saying "What we are going to do next is we are going to do..." when "Let's do" is sufficent. It took a while for me to figure that when the instructor said "lowered" he meant "load" or when he said "forum" he meant "form" etc. Sometimes whole sentences just didn't make any sense.

- A colleague said he avoided the course because of the heavy accent and the "creepy" trailer video. The tiny head on a vast screen background that is used for several lessons is bizarre. Make the presenter image bigger if it's just going to be used as a talking head against a static background!

- Don't just talk AT your viewers. Structure the sections into formal areas (there is way too much overlap and the different sections almost seem to be just placed at random points too often). Test the viewers at the end of each section to make sure they have understood the main concepts.

Like I said, it's a good course on the basic patterns for RxJS and the instructor clearly knows his stuff and there is nothing else out there I've found that covers this difficult area. I just wish that the course had been less repetitive and made better use of modern training tools to get the basic messages across. Buried in this course is an excellent 2.5 hour course here that is stretched out too far because of the obsession with stretching the artificial Observer Pattern discusson over so many of the opening sections when one shorter section would have been more than enough.  The whole argument seemed spurious anyway because a simple singleton service (rather than putting all the code inside controller classes) which is what most beginner Angular developers would do would have fixed the "problems" the instructor spent two hours trying to use to justify the use of RxJS.

results.content: This is a  great course, my favorite part is that the instructor will show you why other approaches do not work. This is powerful information when you work with a team of other developers that typically expect you to prove to them why their approach will not work and yours will. It's not often you get this kind of teaching, most tech courses will cover the topic you are trying to learn but not many will teach you why you should not use a certain approach. Normally this is learned on the job after spending months of coding and company resources building something the wrong way.

results.content:
This was a great course in the sense that it introduced us to some reactive patterns that proove to be very useful. The introduction part of this course (Observable and Reactive Pattern) was, I think, the most useful part to get to know the basis of Reactive Programming. 

I did not give this course a higher rating because, even though the content is good, I was expecting a more detailed course (some of the operators or some concepts were not deeply explained or presented, just a brief mention and use), and this course obviously needs an update (the implementations and operators used were old versions, some of them even deprecated).

results.content:
This course is right for you if you are interested in understanding 2 things

1. The basic building blocks of RxJs
2. How angular uses Rxjs

If you are looking for a course which focuses more on the concepts rather than jamming through Rx operators this course is ideal for you. 

I really enjoyed the hands on exercise which has more focus on building a real application. The course doesen't use the new RxJs6 style of operators however this problem can easily be solved quickly by doing a bit of research and does not take anything away from the course. 

Thanks for the brilliant course. I really enjoyed it.

results.content:
Vasco presents in this course a good set of real life features common to various applications.
He constructed the course in a problem / solution manner (like the rest of the Angular University courses) - which helps to understand why some pattern is useful and how it helps to improve the code base.
The focus of the course is why and how to implement the feature not how to type it in. I've seen a lot of courses on Udemy where instructors spend half of the time on typing the boiler plate or manually adding imports .... what a waste of time.
Thank you Vasco - this course is very useful and precise!

results.content:
PROS:
- explanation from the basics (event bus concept in relation to observables concept)
- practical, isolated cookbooks for real life problems
- I understood store pattern based on BehaviorSubject, finally! ;)

CONS:
- outdated in multiple places: RxJS uses pipe instead of chaining, had problems with Firebase working in Angular 9, component variables (that drive template data) modified in Observable.subscribe() do not work (at least for me) - Angular doesn't refresh component view. Had to use async pipe subscribing to Observable from the beginning of certain parts. Generally in multiple places couldn't follow with tutorial, but rather adjust code to recent packages versions.

Very good tutorial despite the outdated parts!
results.content_html:

results.content: I would like to share my opinion about the course. There are some advantages and disadvantages so it depends on you what do you expect this course to give you. If it comes to advantages, there are some interesting usecases of RxJS especially presenting RxJS in comparison with the standard event handling model, so if you want to get some experience in using RxJS, this course can be helpful. On the other hand there are some bugs that shouldn't take place in such a course. I resolved one of these issues in the questions section of the course. Some bugs are related to missing data type declarations. Also the standard event handling model could have been presented in a better way to avoid multiple data owners issue. The author didn't answer any of my questions, so don't count on help from Vasco. Summarizing - if you can and you want to resolve all issues on your own you can learn some intresting things from this course.

results.content:
The title of course was a little misleading (at least for me) - I expected much more details to RxJs and its operators, while about 3/4 of course was dedicated purely to usage of RxJS in Angular and various patterns.

At the start, though, I got some better understanding of Observable, Observer, Subject pattern.

But in principle, if you are interested about various patterns how RxJS can be used in Angular - the course is worth taking.

One point although - there are some bugs to be fixed in working branches cloned from github - it took me some time to find answers in Q&A (for example, next = () => {} instead of plain next() {} to be used, otherwise not rendering in lesson 34 or 35, and issue in lesson 40 with this.db.list in course-detail.component in branch stateless-services).
In lesson 70 and 77 there were some issues (but can be found in Q&A section) - so at the end I did it till the end, and can say that my knowledge improved. So it is worth its money (with discount of course, not full price! :)))

results.content: Superb content. The course goes pretty deep to explain the Observable concept which was exactly what I needed. It's a pretty huge paradigm shift if you're used to developing apps in AngularJS and the course did a good job of demonstrating how not to do things and then explaining how to do them well. The course also gave provided insights into various patterns for Angular which you wouldn't get from simply going through official Angular docs. Would definitely recommend the course to anyone who wishes to understand how to do Angular well.

results.content:
Hello Vasco,

the big problem of your course is the "lag" between the code in the video and the downloaded code from github.

The arguments are intresting and very well exposed but I spent too much time to make your downloaded code usable with the current version of the libraries and framework.

The final consideration, I prefer write all the code instead download branches.

For me the best method, based on my Udemy student experience, is attach the initial code at the begining of the lesson/section and the final code at the end, so if something is wrong it is easy to debug it.

The very last thing, please update the videos and the code at the last Angular and RXJS version.

results.content:
The course created just to cover a specific set of topics, no more. As an experienced developer with (~15y of experience), I just filter out the rubbish stuff and focusing on ng parts I don't know well. Some "patterns", not patterns at all it just a fancy word that is overused here. Dear Author, please check out what a pattern really means.

The main problem is teaching really bad architecture and practices could be extremely dangerous for inexperienced devs.

Regards, Alexey

results.content:
Déçu par ce cours. Le code est obsolète à partir du moment ou on utilise angularFire. Des erreurs de compilation à chaque nouvelle leçon. Le formateur fait trop de copié collé. Certaines parties du code sont modifiées sans être mentionné, il faut faire des pauses pour s'apercevoir de la modification.
Les git checkout ne sont pas une bonne idée car on ne se rend pas compte d'une leçon à l'autre les parties du code qui ont changé. Si on veut suivre sur son propre repository local, il est nécessaire de reprendre tout le code à chaque fois.
L'intention de ce cours est bonne mais une mise à jour du code est nécessaire.

results.content:
Firstly, it was too many introduction videos with no valuable information. The instructor repeated himself very often for no reason... Especially annoying was hearing the exact same unnecessary, not related to the course subject itself, information you've already heard just a couple min ago in the previous video. Course could be much more brief and straight-to-the-point. 

Gladly, situation got better in the next sections. 

Secondly, the code style is a bit untidy and some peaces related to the course main subject are outdated at all (for example chaining RxJS operators instead of using .pipe() method) etc. Not critical, but in my opinion bad form...

I think it is not a good approach to not update dependencies and force students to use old versions of packages to avoid code compile problems. Because programming itself is a quick booming industry and there are many valuable points for being always up-to-date. So, a a much better way would be at least providing text sections with the latest changes and a brief info how to implement new approaches if a student wants too...

So, little bit of refactoring and updating with the latest relevant technics would be really nice.

results.content:
Th ereworked course is (so far) better than the original, foe me. Content, approach, clarity are all still excellent.

What I'm missing so far (-1/2 star) is a discussion/examples of how testing would happen in a reactive style application.

I'd be interested in some instruction on more advanced application concerns ... a Masterclass including more RxJS operators ... show how to use timeouts in a reactive app ... show how to present partial results from the back end ... discuss network/battery impact of various designs, etc (Suppose I have a back end delivering 100 lessons of a course, and I want to show a progress bar that ticks as each 10 are received, or if I get a partial trasfer like 89 of the lessons, I want to keep that much and just warn the user the network was interrupted, etc ... typical 'mobile' stuff.

All that said, let me repeat: I enjoyed the course, and I learned a lot!

results.content:
I can't understate how great of a communicator Vasco is.  He really is a master of explaining things.  You really get a deep understanding of how things are done, why things are done in a certain way, and why you should use a certain approach.  

Just three gotchas:
- If you want to just know how to do things, this course isn't for you.  Like I said, this course really goes over the intricacies of patterns and what specific problems they solve.  You *will* have a great understanding of observables after this class.
- Vasco goes really fast.  I had to stop, take notes, and  replay parts multiple times.
- The way the branching is set up in the source code forces you to code along.  When he tells you to switch to a branch in the code, it sets up the code at the beginning of the lesson.  If you want just the answers, you have to go to the branch used in the beginning of the next lesson.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Excellent course.  Vasco doesn't disappoint, as always.  I have taken several courses related to Angular 2+ on Udemy and Vasco with his Angular University is a great instructor.  He is a great programmer and structures his courses very well so that the student has enough time to digest the concepts.  I really like his approach of showing a not-so-good way of implementing a feature and then refactoring using a cutting edge technique made possible (and relatively easy) with Angular 2+, RxJS, Reactive Programming, etc.

I have only good things to say about Vasco and his courses.  They are packed with great techniques and the whole Angular University resources (YouTube channel, the official Angular University website, ...) makes it a very pleasant and efficient way of keeping up-to-date on the evolution of Angular and the surrounding JS ecosystem.

Highly recommended.

results.content: The content is a good building block for understanding reactive design and specifically the RxJS library. The biggest stumbling block is figuring out how to bridge the gap between the proof-of-concept examples provided in the videos, and a real-world application that needs things like AuthGuards, routing, error recovery, other components that need to know about the user's authentication state (not just the template), and then how do we test all this code?
